title: 115_hr1140
content: The Act may be cited as the "WMATA Improvement Act of 2017" and authorizes grants. The "WMATA Improvement Act of 2017" authorizes grants for the Transit Authority for capital and preventive maintenance projects, with a maximum amount of $75,000,000 per fiscal year from 2018 to 2028. The Federal share of project costs cannot exceed 50%, with the remaining costs split equally between the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Virginia, and the State of Maryland. The "WMATA Improvement Act of 2017" authorizes grants for the Transit Authority for capital and preventive maintenance projects, with a maximum amount of $75,000,000 per fiscal year from 2018 to 2028. Grants provided under this section are subject to specific terms and conditions, including amendments to collective bargaining agreements for operational changes. The "WMATA Improvement Act of 2017" allows for grants to the Transit Authority for projects aimed at improving service, reliability, safety, and cost efficiency through competitive bidding for certain capital projects. Any agreements made must comply with specific laws and collective bargaining agreements entered into after January 1, 2017, may be considered amended agreements. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO WMATA COMPACT. The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Compact must include amendments requiring Board members to have a primary fiduciary obligation and expert qualifications. The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Compact mandates that Board members must have expert qualifications, including a certified management expert with experience managing over 1,000 employees and a certified financial expert meeting audit committee standards. The Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Compact requires Board members to have specific qualifications, including a certified safety expert with 5 years of experience in transportation safety and a qualifying business definition. Additionally, an amendment mandates the Board of Directors to consist of 9 members appointed by different entities. The Board of Directors for the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority includes two members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation and the CEO of the Transit Authority. If the signatories of the Compact fail to enact the described amendments within 18 months of the Act's enactment, congressional consent for the Compact will be withdrawn. An extension of 3 months may be granted by the Secretary of Transportation if progress is shown towards implementing the amendments. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "Compact" refers to the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority Compact, and "Transit Authority" refers to the Washington Metropolitan Area Transit Authority.
